heading: 1.1 OpenLandMap project
text:
OpenLandMap Open Land Data services providing access spatial layers
covering global land mass (spatial resolutions 1 km, 250 m finer) hosted OpenGeoHub foundation, GILAB.rs collaborators.
aims becoming OpenStreetMap-type system land data. Access spatial layers 
possible via interactive visualizations /Open Source software solutions.
Read project .OpenLandMap layers, specified otherwise, licensed 
Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International license (CC -SA) /
Open Data Commons Open Database License (ODbL). implies anyone can use,
build upon, OpenLandMap data without restrictions.
See Copyright License page details.
Figure 1.1: Example 3D soil information: soil pH visualized different depths.
Users can access OpenLandMap data via five main channels:OpenLandMap App https://openlandmap.org,OpenLandMap training points https://gitlab.com/openlandmap/compiled-ess-point-data-sets,OpenGeoHub STAC installation https://stac.opengeohub.org,OpenLandMap REST API services https://api.openlandmap.org,OpenLandMap Wasabi service see detailed tutorial,Zenodo.org access (version-controlled) back-copy data via DOI,Data portal https://openlandmap.org landing page (running Geoserver + OpenLayers) users can browse maps, query values 
location, find recent news activities. STAC https://stac.opengeohub.org
generic layer repository accessing layers installed maintained OpenGeoHub.
allow users .e. producers layers edit update metadata descriptions,
create map views, learn use WCS, WMS similar. copy raw data can obtained
via zenodo.org similar public data repositories.training data repository contains
import processing steps run clean standardize global compilations training
points, importantly land cover, vegetation, meteo, soil ecological observations.

heading: 1.2 Accessing data
text:
OpenLandMap data can best accessed using OpenLandMap Wasabi file service.
service based Cloud-Optimized GeoTIFFs 
probably also best solution spatial queries spatial analysis. Wasabi
service explained detail COG tutorial.

heading: 1.2.1 OpenLandMap REST API
text:
OpenLandMap data services REST API (https://api.openlandmap.org) contains scripts functions
allow users developers fetch raw data (point queries) simple textual
formats GeoJSON, csv, compressed GeoTIFFs similar. following query fetch monthly precipitations location X, Y:results :determine soil type (USDA great group) use:gives e.g.:list available layers use: https://api.openlandmap.org/query/populateTo query values multiple points (currently limited max 50 points)
provide GeoJSON point feature collection layer name table:test_points.geojson GeoJSON file containing coordinates points.
examples construct spatial queries available :
https://api.openlandmap.orgIn addition REST access, can access OpenLandMap data using 
Wasabi file service. recommend using Wasabi file service overlay, download parts data.
downloading whole GeoTIFFs recommend instead using Zenodo.
code:
https://api.openlandmap.org/query/point?lat=7.58033&lon=35.6561&coll=layers1km&regex=clm_precipitation_imerge.(jan|feb|mar|apr|may|jun|jul|aug|sep|oct|nov|dec)_m_1km_s0..0cm_.*_v0.1.tifProject description

heading: 1.2.2 Accessing data from Zenodo
text:
download whole layers zenodo can use R packages jsonlite RCurl:first need authenticate using Zenodo API TOKEN
(see: obtain API TOKEN):download MODIS LST images 1 km can use bucket ID dep.id = "1435938" gives:shows total 102 files folder. download temperatures August,
hence use:gives total 9 files:can downloaded using download.file function similar.
also R package zenodo (zen4R) makes downloading files even easier.
code:
library(jsonlite)
library(RCurl)
library(rgdal)
TOKEN = scan("~/TOKEN_ACCESS", what="character")dep.id = "1435938"
x = fromJSON(system(paste0('curl -H \"Accept: application/json\" -H \"Authorization: Bearer ', 
        TOKEN, '\" \"https://www.zenodo.org/api/deposit/depositions/', dep.id, '\"'), intern=TRUE))

heading: 1.2.3 Accessing data from Google Earth Engine
text:
Google Earth Engine users can access snapshot OpenLandMap.org layers using following address:https://code.earthengine.google.com/?asset=users/opengeohub/openlandmapDescription layer names units used can find .
Note sync layers OpenLandMap.org Google Earth Engine done
year, hence, wish use --date layers moment,
downloading maps either Zenodo via Wasabi service recommended.access OpenLandMap layers can also refer public data sets :https://developers.google.com/earth-engine/datasets/tags/openlandmap

heading: 1.3 The file naming convention
text: OpenLandMap file-naming convention works 10 fields basically define important properties data (way users can search files, prepare data analysis etc, without even needing access open files. 10 fields include:Generic variable name (needs unique): lcluVariable procedure combination .e. method standard (standard abbreviation): esa.cciPosition probability distribution / variable type: cSpatial support (usually horizontal block) m km: 250mDepth reference depth interval e.g. (“b”), (“”) ground surface (“s”) b{depth}{metric length} certain depth. e.g. b30cm. interval like go b{depth}t{depth}{metric length}: b30t60cmTime reference begin time (YYYYMMDD): 20210101Time reference end time: 20211231Bounding box (2 letters max): goEPSG code: epsg.4326Version code .e. creation date: v20221015An example file-name based description :following variable types currently supported:m= mean value;q.10 = 10% probability quantile (one side probability);d= median value; equivalent q.50;c= class factor / requires domain codes / levels;cd = change class (special cross-domain 2D matrix);p= probability 0–100%;sse = Shannon Scaled Entropy index;l.159= lower 68% probability threshold (quantile);u.841= upper 68% probability threshold (quantile), one-sided probability use “q”,pc= percent cover pixel 0–100%;sd= standard deviation prediction error; multiple standard deviation use e.g. “sd.2”md = model deviation (case ensemble predictions);si= confidence interval range prediction mean value;td = cumulative difference (usually based time-series values);Note file naming convention following properties:Large quantities files can easily sorted searched (one line queries Bash).File-naming patterns can used seamlessly build virtual mosaics composites.Key spatiotemporal properties data available file name e.g. variable type, O&M method, spatial resolution, bounding box, projection system, temporal references. Users can program analysis without opening testing files.Versioning system ubiquitous.file-names unique.Geonetwork STAC used link unique file names : (1) WPs, deliverables, themes / keywords, (2) DOI’s, (3) project homepages, (4) contact pages support feedback. keywords recommend using INSPIRE keywords. confirm metadata complete consistent, recommend using INSPIRE metadata validator /https://data.europa.eu/en validator.simple additional rules generating file name include:Codes abbreviations human-readable much possible (hence short, short!);Use English-US (en-us) language e.g. months use “jan”, “feb” etc;Consistently use UNICODE standard: non-ASCII characters;Limit total file name size characters : 256;time reference extend beyond hour minute timezone;non-standard non-EPSG projections please register projection first obtain code Spatial Reference List;bounding boxes use much possible 2–letter unique country code; continents use Equi7 Grid codes global products use “go” global land without Antarctica, “ga” full global coverage,method codes use much possible unique IDs ISO - ICS;MODIS products use consistently MODIS products codes e.g. MOD11A2 v061;long-term aggregates seasonal, monthly, weekly values use period name end method names (#3) example long-term estimate MODIS LST daytime temperature month August:list vocabularies used abbreviated names variables provided OpenGeoHub. file-name convention described can also used vector data (different file extension) also.

heading: 1.4 The land mask
text:
bounding box interest OpenLandMap data :image sizes various standard resolutions :250m = 172800P x 71698L,500m = 86400P x 35849L,1km = 43200P x 17924L,
Figure 1.2: OpenLandMap world land mask: derived using ESA land cover time series maps 2000–2015. Red areas indicate barren lands, light green indicates permanent ice areas.
standard spatial resolutions derived using simple
rule thumb:250 m = 1/480 d.d. = 0.002083333500 m = 1/240 d.d. = 0.0041666671 km = 1/120 d.d. = 0.008333333OpenLandMap works standard land mask derived using ESA time series land cover maps 2000–2015:📂 Download layerIt contains following values:1 = land (remaining pixels permanent water, desert ice)1 = land (remaining pixels permanent water, desert ice)2 = permanent water bodies (consistently water body 2000–2015)2 = permanent water bodies (consistently water body 2000–2015)3 = permanent bare areas (consistently bare areas /
deserts 2000–2015)3 = permanent bare areas (consistently bare areas /
deserts 2000–2015)4 = permanent ice (consistently ice 2000–2015)4 = permanent ice (consistently ice 2000–2015)need global equal area projection (e.g. able derive total stocks / density features N/km-squared)
advise using Goode Homolosine projection:
Figure 1.3: OpenLandMap world mask Goode Homolosine projection: 100 100 km blocks land mask Goode Homolosine projection.
📂 Download layerThe bounding box case :corresponding image sizes :250m = 172800P x 71698L,
code:
Xmin = -180.00000
Ymin = -62.00081
Xmax = 179.99994
Ymax = 87.37000lcv_landmask_esacci.lc.l4_c_250m_s0..0cm_2000..2015_v1.0.tif+proj=igh +ellps=WGS84 +units=m +no_defsXmin = -20037508
Ymin = -6728980

Ymax = 8421750

heading: 1.5 Cloud-optimized GeoTIFF
text:
layers included OpenLandMap system pre-processed following GDAL’s cloud-optimized GeoTIFF
instructions. process large (global land mask 250 m resolution finer) GeoTIFFs please use following
settings:prepare cloud-optimized GeoTIFF use:add tiles optimize compression. CO=YES indicates GeoTIFF cloud-optimized.OpenLandMap.org COG’s available publicly without restrictions via 
Wasabi file service.
code:
gdalwarp layer.vrt layer.tif 
   -ot COG
   -tr 0.002083333 0.002083333 
   -te -180.00000 -62.00081 179.99994 87.37000
   -wm 2000 -co \"BIGTIFF=YES\"gdaladdo layer.tif -r near 2 4 8 16 32 64 128
gdal_translate layer.tif layer-co.tif -mo \"CO=YES\" -co \"TILED=YES\" -co \"BLOCKXSIZE=512\" 
        -co \"BLOCKYSIZE=512\" -co \"COMPRESS=LZW\" -co \"COPY_SRC_OVERVIEWS=YES\" 
        --config GDAL_TIFF_OVR_BLOCKSIZE 512

heading: 1.6 Relief and geology
text:
Relief parameters derived derived using SAGA GIS (http://www.saga-gis.org/)
MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) projected Equi7 grid system
(Bauer-Marschallinger et al. 2014). derived, DEM derivatives 
reprojected lon-lat system. See processing steps.

heading: 1.6.1 Slope in radians
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) derived using SAGA GIS Equi7 grid system.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.2 SAGA Topographic Wetness Index (TWI)
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) derived using SAGA GIS Equi7 grid system.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.3 Module Multiresolution Index of Valley Bottom Flatness (MRVBF)
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) derived using SAGA GIS Equi7 grid system.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.4 Rock type
text:
Based USGS Global Ecophysiography map / Global Lithological Map database v1.1 (GLiM, Hartmann Moosdorf, 2012).📂 Download layer
:information_source: Classes

heading: 1.6.5 Landform class
text:
Based USGS Global Ecophysiography map (Sayre et al. 2014).📂 Download layer
:information_source: ClassesUSGS Global Ecophysiography map property U.S. Department Interior, U.S. Geological Survey.

heading: 1.6.6 Density of Earthquakes for the last 100 years
text:
Based USGS global earthquakes database (http://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/). considered earthquakes magntiude 4 higher (405,885 quakes total).
Processing steps explained .📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.7 Cosine of the aspect
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al., 2019) described Amatulli, McInerney, Sethi, Strobl, & Domisch (2020) “Geomorpho90m” dataset.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.8 Sine of the aspect
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset).📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.9 Convergence
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset). Derived using GRASS Equi7 grid system.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.10 Compound topographic index
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset). Derived using GRASS Equi7 grid system.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.11 Maximum multiscale deviation
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset). Derived using WHITEBOX Equi7 grid system.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.12 Scale of the maximum multiscale deviation
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset). Derived using WHITEBOX Equi7 grid system.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.13 Easthness
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset). Derived using GDAL.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.14 Geomorphon clasess
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset). Derived using GRASS Equi7 grid system. See description geomorphon classes.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.15 Northness
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset). Derived using GDAL.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.16 Profile curvature
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset). Derived using GRASS Equi7 grid system.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.17 Maximum multiscale roughness
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset). Derived using WHITEBOX Equi7 grid system.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.18 Roughness
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset). Derived using GDAL.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.19 Scale of the maximum multiscale roughness
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset). Derived using WHITEBOX Equi7 grid system.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.6.20 Tangential curvature
text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset). Derived using GRASS Equi7 grid system.📂 Download layer

text: Based MERIT DEM (Yamazaki et al. 2017) described Amatulli et al. (2019; Geomorpho90m dataset). Derived using GRASS Equi7 grid system.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.7 Land cover, land use and administrative data
1.7.1 Land cover images for 1992 to 2018
text:
Based European Space Agency (ESA) Climate Change Initiative (ESACCI-LC).📂 Download layer
:information_source: ClassesCCI Land cover time series © ESA Climate Change Initiative — Land Cover led UCLouvain (2017).

heading: 1.7.2 Surface water occurrence probability
text:
Based Pekel et al. (2016) / provided EC Joint Research Centre.
download higher resolution version map visit https://global-surface-water.appspot.com/📂 Download layer

heading: 1.7.3 Nightlights changes
text: 2nd principal component based Version 4 DMSP-OLS Nighttime Lights Time Series 1997–2014. See processing steps.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.7.4 Croplands historic
text:
Time-series maps showing cropland evolution past 12,000 years
based HYDE v3.2 data set (Klein Goldewijk et al. 2017).📂 Download layer

heading: 1.7.5 Pastures historic
text:
Time-series maps showing pastures evolution past 12,000 years
based HYDE v3.2 data set (Klein Goldewijk et al. 2017).📂 Download layerHistoric land use maps HYDE data set property Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency (PBL).

heading: 1.7.6 Land cover images (100m)
text: Produced global component Copernicus Land Service, derived PROBA-V satellite observations ancillary datasets.📂 Download layerTo explore download global 100-m resolution land cover maps please use https://lcviewer.vito..

heading: 1.8 Vegetation indices
text:
FAPAR vegetation indices derived using quantile function data.table package.
detailed processing steps please refer Hengl et al. (2018).

heading: 1.8.1 FAPAR median monthly value 2014–2017
text: Based Copernicus PROB-V FAPAR product.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.8.2 FAPAR median annual value 2014–2017
text: Based Copernicus PROB-V FAPAR product.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.8.3 Time-series Gapfilled NDVI P90 AVHRR 1982–2019
text: Based AVHRR NDVI product.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.9.1 Soil organic carbon stock change (0–30 cm)
text:
Estimated SOC loss (0–30 cm) based European Space Agency (ESA) Climate Change Initiative
(ESACCI-LC) land cover maps 2001–2015. shows estimated SOC loss (kg/m2) result 
change land use / land cover. See processing steps.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.9.2 Tree-covered and intact forest landscapes
text:
Based UNEP historic forest cover map, ESA land cover time series 
intact forest landscape (IFL 2000, 2013 2016) data (Potapov et al. 2013).
two classes considered: (1) intact forest areas, (2) tree-covered areas. See processing steps.📂 Download layerThe intact forest landscapes project supported University Maryland, Greenpeace, World Resources Institute, Transparent World.

heading: 1.9.3 Landscape degradation degree
text: Based comparison land cover changes 9 km search radius (Nowosad et al., 2018).📂 Download layerProduced Space Informatics Lab, University Cincinnati.

heading: 1.10 Climatic layers
text:
Climatic layers available resolution 1 km 500 m.
Long-term Land Surface Temperature derived MODIS MOD11A2
Land Surface Temperature (LST) images 2000–2017 using data.table package quantile function R.
See processing steps.
MODIS land products property Land Processes Distributed Active Archive Center, U.S. Geological Survey.

heading: 1.10.1 Long-term Land Surface Temperature daytime monthly mean
text: Based MODIS MOD11A2 Land Surface Temperature (LST) images 2000–2017.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.10.2 Long-term Land Surface Temperature daytime monthly sd
text: Based MODIS MOD11A2 Land Surface Temperature (LST) images 2000–2017.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.10.3 Long-term Land Surface Temperature monthly day-night difference
text: Based MODIS MOD11A2 Land Surface Temperature (LST) images 2000–2017.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.10.4 Precipitation monthly in mm
text: Based Global Precipitation Measurement Integrated Multi-satellitE Retrievals GPM (IMERG) 2014–2018 WorldClim v2 (Fick Hijmans 2017), CHELSA climate (Karger et al. 2017) rainfall monthly images.📂 Download layerGlobal Precipitation Measurement Integrated Multi-satellitE Retrievals GPM (IMERG) provided NASA Goddard Space Flight Center.

heading: 1.10.5 Snow probability monthly
text: Based CCI Land Cover dataset / MOD10A2 product 500 m period 2000–2012.📂 Download layer

heading: 1.11 Soil properties and classes
text:
mapping soil properties classes use compilation published point data
coming various national international soil point data providers.
important sources training points include:USDA National Cooperative Soil Characterization Database,Africa Soil Profiles Database,LUCAS Soil database,Repositório Brasileiro Livre para Dados Abertos Solo (FEBR),Sistema de Información de Suelos de Latinoamérica y el Caribe (SISLAC),Northern Circumpolar Soil Carbon Database (NCSCD),Dokuchaev Soil Science Institute / Ministry Agriculture Russia (soil profiles Russia),WHRC global mangrove soil carbon dataset,Local data sets Silva et al. (2019),Additional points, available databases, also imported WoSIS Soil Profile Database (Batjes et al. 2017).Predictions based 3D Machine Learning ensemble models estimated using
SuperLearner caret packages. Predictive Soil Mapping steps sample outputs 
described detail Hengl MacMillan (2019).soil variable names use consistently National Cooperative Soil Characterization Database
column names codes. example:refers db_od column database 4a1h laboratory method (bulk density oven-dry), described :Laboratory Methods Manual (SSIR 42) - NRCS - USDA,Soil Survey Field Laboratory Methods Manual - NRCS - USDAContinuous 3D soil properties predicted 6 standard depths:0, 10, 30, 60, 100 200 cmand aggregated standard depth intervals (5):0–10, 10–30, 30–60, 60–100 100–200 cmStandard prediction errors (eithers prediction variance prediction confidence limits)
provided soil property / depth. example:contains standard deviation ensemble models (independent prediction variance). md provides estimate prediction error currently can used derive prediction intervals.Data import, overlay model fitting produce predictions soil properties classes 
explained detail . Principles Predictive Soil Mapping outlined detail PSMwR book.
Figure 1.4: OpenLandMap workflow soil mapping: general workflow generation soil properties classes using Machine Learning.
Several improvements implemented spatial prediction soil properties classes (comparison Hengl et al. 2017, Sanderman et al. 2017):New RS-based layers added list covariates including Copernicus FAPAR time series images,
MERIT DEM multiscale DEM derivatives, ALOS radar images, MODIST LST aggregates IMERGE precipitation images,New RS-based layers added list covariates including Copernicus FAPAR time series images,
MERIT DEM multiscale DEM derivatives, ALOS radar images, MODIST LST aggregates IMERGE precipitation images,Selection ensemble model now run via SuperLearner package framework, allows incorporating spatial subsetting Cross-Validation models,Selection ensemble model now run via SuperLearner package framework, allows incorporating spatial subsetting Cross-Validation models,estimate prediction uncertainty / error provided via ensemble model standard deviation,estimate prediction uncertainty / error provided via ensemble model standard deviation,Soil type maps now based 360,000 training points (compare ca 70,000 previous run),Soil type maps now based 360,000 training points (compare ca 70,000 previous run),point quality flag (completeness) used case.weights training process,point quality flag (completeness) used case.weights training process,Artifacts / extrapolation problems, especially soil carbon maps, now dealt using --date (ESA) land cover map,Artifacts / extrapolation problems, especially soil carbon maps, now dealt using --date (ESA) land cover map,use soil maps combination local data (e.g. produce ensemble finer resolution maps local areas),
consider following approaches:Manon, C., Dobarco, M.R, Arrouays, D., Minasny, B. N.P.. Saby. (2019). “Merging Country, Continental Global Predictions Soil Texture: Lessons Ensemble Modelling France.” Geoderma 337: 99–110. https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.geoderma.2018.09.007.Ramcharan, ., Hengl, T., Nauman, T., Brungard, C., Waltman, S., Wills, S., & Thompson, J. (2018). “Soil Property Class Maps Conterminous United States 100-Meter Spatial Resolution.” Soil Science Society America Journal, 82(1), 186-201. https://dl.sciencesocieties.org/publications/sssaj/abstracts/82/1/186
